addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

section.hand:
25 Ju
l
1592 M
r
Bodeley.
loss of
fauma

page.lettertext:
fol.130r
May it please yo
r
good L. Upon my letters
unto yow of
e 15 16 and 19 of this present,
I doe onely nowe attend, what her
Ma
tie
will
commaund, for dispatche of
e companies. It is
advertised hither
at
e Enemie on
e soddaine hath
passed
e Rhine, between
Berke
and
Wesel,
w
t
a 1000 foote, and 300 horse. Their purpose
is yet unknowen: but it seemeth by conjecture,
that they are called by
Verdugo
to
e castell of
Grolle,
who being there in person, hath a meaning,
as is thought, to doe somwhat by surprise in the
quarters of
Zutphan,
w
ch
are very ill provided
of men and munition, or to seeke to distresse
e
campe before
Coevoerden.
The
Councel
at
Swol
are somwhat troubled w
t
this occurrence,
and have written earnestly unto me, that the
Englishe enseignes might be suffered to repaire
unto
e campe: or at lest to come from
Hattem,
Harderwicke,
Elbourgh,
and those other places re-
mote, where they lie nowe in garrison, and be
placed at
Disbourgh,
for
e assurance of
at
towne, and of
e contrey joining to it. The
self same motion hath bin made by
e
states
that
are heere, w
t
urgent speeches of persuasion, to
drawe me to allowe their comming to
e campe.
But both mine answear unto them, and to the
Councel of estate, hath bin to this effect, that my
Commission was precise to put
e Companies in
a readines w
t
all expedition, and to send them
presently from hens, when her Hig
nes
should re-
quire it. This could not be perfourmed, nor
I excused in my dealing, if her Ma
tie
having notice
of their being in garrison, and we expecting
fol.130v
every houre for their calling from hens, they should
be sent abroad againe, to doe some service at the
campe. Howbeit for
at other point of their de-
maund, to have them placed in
Disbourgh, because
I was assured
at
e good estate of
e contrey
was highly tendred by her Ma
tie
and
at to send
e troupes no further, could impeache but very
litle their continuance in a readines, I would write
about it to
S
r
Francis Vere
(who remaineth at
Utrecht
)
and his opinion therein concurring w
t
mine, wherof
I doubted not at all, their turne in
at respect should
be presently served. I knowe not howe
e Coun-
cel will accept of this answear, but
e states are
not pleased,
at their power should be restrained in
commaunding
e companies. We have
newes at this present
at
Count Maurice
, having left
Count William
at
e siege of Coeveorden, was gone
himself w
t
some troupes, and certaine peeces of bat-
terie, before
e sconce of
Oetmaersen,
w
ch
belongeth
otmars
e
[r
e
dre]
to
e Enemie in
e southerly part of
Twente.
There were not w
t
in above a 100 souldiers, w
ch
after
e discharge of two or three volies, surren-
dred
e place, upon promise to depart w
t
their wea-
pons, and bagage: but taking an othe, as those of
steenwicke, not to serve
e
King of Spaine
, for
e
space of six monethes, on this side
e Rhine.
The fort, it is thought, doth cost us over deere, having
lost before it, by
e shotte of a muskette,
Monsieur
M
o
s
r
de
Fauma
de Fauma
,
e gouverno
r
of
Huesden
, and generall
of
e artillerie, a gentleman of good qualities,
of great experience in
e warres, and for advise in
all attemptes
e most sufficient of this countrey.
Right nowe this bearer hath brought me a
fol.131r
letter from S
r
Francis Vere, whereby I am infor-
med
at
e Councel of Estate hath written unto
him, to
e self same purpose as to me: to whome
his answear and mine accorded all in one, and
so I thinke by this post he hath written to yo
r
L.
Thus I take my humble leave.
At
e Hage. July 25 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
